MichaelBrown.question: Which component of the system converts the binary symptom vector into disease probabilities?
What is the purpose of one-hot encoding the top-3 diseases before specialist prediction?
options: To create a fixed-length input for logistic regression
To rank the diseases by importance

MichaelBrown.question: What role does the softmax function play in the specialist recommendation model?
options: It chooses the single best specialist
It converts raw model scores into a probability distribution

MichaelBrown.question: Which Random Forest hyperparameter controls the number of trees?
Which Logistic Regression parameter sets the maximum number of training iterations?
What binary vector entry corresponds to the symptom 'fatigue'?
options: 1 if fatigue is present, 0 if absent
The average fatigue score across trees

MichaelBrown.question: What were the top three disease predictions for Michael and their confidences?
Which symptom in Michael's scenario is represented by the feature 'red_spots_over_body'?
Which specialist did the model recommend most strongly for Michael?
Why does the Random Forest average over 200 trees instead of using a single tree?
options: To reduce overfitting and stabilize predictions

MichaelBrown.question: Why might the second-ranked specialist still receive a nonzero probability?
options: Softmax assigns some weight to every class, even low-score ones
Because the model always shows two specialists

MichaelBrown.question: How would removing 'skin_rash' from Michael's inputs affect the disease probabilities?
options: Chicken pox probability would likely decrease
All disease probabilities would sum to more than 100%
Specialist recommendation would stay the same

MichaelBrown.question: Why does the symptom 'red_spots_over_body' increase the probability of Chicken pox?
options: Because it appears in many leaf nodes associated with Chicken pox during training
Because one-hot encoding boosts its weight
Because softmax multiplies it by a constant

MichaelBrown.question: If two patients have identical top-3 disease labels but swapped probabilities (Patient A: [0.50, 0.30, 0.20], Patient B: [0.30, 0.50, 0.20]), how will their specialist recommendations compare?
options: The system will give the same two specialists in the same order
The system will give the same two specialists, but in reversed order
They may get completely different specialists

MichaelBrown.question: Explain in plain words why averaging many trees makes the prediction more stable.
options: It reduces random variance by combining multiple weak learners
It always increases the probability of the first label
It removes the need for softmax

MichaelBrown.question: What question would you ask the LLM to check if the LLM model actually used lab values like CRP in its explanation?
options: Did the model actually use CRP levels as an input feature?
What symptom vector did you use?
How many trees predict Chicken pox?

MichaelBrown.question: Could Michael's red spots be caused by something other than Chicken pox? Which follow-up would probe this?
options: Could rash be caused by allergy rather than Chicken pox?
What is the solver used in Logistic Regression?
How many trees reached a leaf?
What is the Gini impurity value?

MichaelBrown.question: If Michael actually had Lupus (not in top 3) but Lupus scores only 0.05, what might that suggest about the classifier?
options: It may be misclassifying Lupus symptoms as Chicken pox
It grouped Lupus under Hepatitis C

MichaelBrown.question: After Michael's scenario, you notice 'Acne' at 10.5%. What could a user ask to understand why Acne scored lower than Hepatitis C?
options: Which symptom splits favored Hepatitis C over Acne?
How many iterations did the Logistic Regression run?
Why does softmax remove low scores?
What is the patient's CRP level?

JaneSmith.question: Which model component converts Jane's symptom vector into disease probabilities?
What step is necessary for a uniform input to the Logistic Regression model for specialist prediction?
options: One-hot encoding for top 3 disease labels

JaneSmith.question: What is the role of softmax in the specialist model?
options: Converts scores into probabilities summing to 1

JaneSmith.question: Which symptom binary feature corresponds to 'diarrhoea'?
Why does the system present three diseases instead of one?
options: To show model uncertainty and alternatives
Because three labels are required for input

JaneSmith.question: What were Jane's top three diseases and their confidences?
Which specialist did the model recommend most strongly for Jane?
If two patients have different top-3 labels but same probabilities in the same order, how will their specialist recommendations compare?
options: Same two specialists in same order
Same two specialists in reversed order

JaneSmith.question: Why is 'diarrhoea' a strong indicator for Gastroenteritis in the Random Forest?
options: It appears in many decision paths associated with Gastroenteritis
It is ignored by Gini impurity

JaneSmith.question: How would removing 'vomiting' from Jane's input likely affect the probabilities?
options: Specialist recommendation would switch to Cardiologist

JaneSmith.question: What would happen if only two disease labels were passed to the specialist classifier?
options: It would still output probabilities but with less context
It would output only one specialist

JaneSmith.question: Explain in simple terms why averaging tree outputs reduces overfitting.
options: It smooths out individual tree errors by combining many opinions
It always chooses the most common label

JaneSmith.question: Which symptom from Jane's input is most likely ignored by the model?
options: None - all binary symptom features are processed by the model
Vomiting - it is not encoded numerically

JaneSmith.question: Could Jane's diarrhoea be caused by something other than Gastroenteritis? What would you ask?
options: Could loose stools indicate IBS or food intolerance instead?
Why does the model need 200 trees?

JaneSmith.question: Which follow-up question would reveal if the model used lab values like CRP?
options: Did the model actually use CRP levels as an input feature?

JaneSmith.question: If a real case of IBS (not in top 3) scored 0.08, what might that suggest?
options: The model confuses IBS with Gastroenteritis
It was grouped under Chronic cholestasis

JaneSmith.question: After Jane sees Chronic cholestasis at 22.0%, which question probes why it wasn't top-1?
options: Which symptom splits favored Gastroenteritis over cholestasis?

JaneSmith.question: If Gastroenteritis and Heartburn share symptoms, what could make the model prefer one over the other?
options: Symptom frequency and training data leaf distributions
The order of symptoms in input

JaneSmith.question: A user sees Malaria at 10.5% and wonders if it's significant. What does this score indicate?
options: Low likelihood but not ruled out entirely

Specialist recommended would switch to Cardiologist

AliceJohnson.question: Why might the Random Forest associate 'slurred_speech' more with neurological issues than metabolic ones?
options: It rarely appears outside neurology-related leaf nodes
It is ignored by Gini impurity

AliceJohnson.question: Why might Hypoglycemia still appear with 21% despite being third?
options: It shares overlapping symptoms with higher-ranked diseases
It was added by the LLM

AliceJohnson.question: What would happen if only one disease label were passed to the specialist model?
options: It would reduce context and possibly give skewed probabilities
The softmax would output binary values
It would average the missing classes

AliceJohnson.question: Explain why averaging many decision trees reduces model variance.

It always picks the tree with the highest depth
It reduces the number of features

AliceJohnson.question: If the true cause were stroke (not in top 3) scoring 0.08, what does that suggest?

How many features are used by softmax?

AliceJohnson.question: Alice is told Neurologist (92%) and Endocrinologist (4%) are top picks. What explains the specialist split?
options: Neurologist is more directly tied to top disease (Migraine); Endocrinologist maps to Hypoglycemia

Which symptom corresponds to 'chills' in Emily's case?

options: Combining multiple tree opinions smooths out individual errors
It always picks the deepest tree
It changes symptoms to lab values

It would generate a different one-hot encoding

options: The model may confuse dengue with Malaria

That Heart Attack was highly likely
